column4: hey guys, is it possible that scripts in /etc/cron.daily were not executed on a server (so always running) in Ubuntu 8.04 ?
in /etc/crontab I find lines which test for anacron's existence, if it's there they do nothing... and anacron is started on boot, but exits after running all jobs that were left out
so how is anacron going to run those jobs?
and in crontab the lines look like this: test -x /usr/sbin/anacron || ( cd / && run-parts --report /etc/cron.daily )
(cron is running)
but as anacron is installed it tests for its existence and quits without invoking it
are jobs in /etc/cron.daily executed on a daily basis even when the server is not rebooted?
if yes: by hom?
s/hom/whom/
all the scripts in the directory will be run *if* /usr/sbin/anacron is executable.  They will be run by root as per the crontab entry.
no, that would be &&
the || acts as a stop if the first argument exits with a status of 1 otherwise the second will proceed
in what language?
shell script (sh, bash, etc.)
just go to your shell and write this: "true || echo 'something'"
You still around?
yupp
Yeah, I inadvertently misled you earlier.  If the anacron is executable then *don't* execute run-parts.  Sorry about that.  I always forget that an exit status of 0 is success, not 1!  :-)
actually I see that the problem is solved in 10.04 by including an anacron cronjob: /etc/cron.d/anacron the line which is commented out is the one I use now ;)

but would be nice to see this backported to 8.04 (it's actually only adding this file in the anacron package). I regard this a serious security problem as it hindered my server updating its antivir-db for months now
